basics.name: Siddharth Sharma
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary: Hi! I am Siddharth. I am a software engineer at Samsung Research, Bengaluru. Currently, I am working on using deep learning techniques to provide image enhancement solutions. My interests lie in computer vision, securing machine learning models, and number theory.

work.name: Samsung Research Institute
highlights: Working in the AI Video Processing Lab on image enhancement solutions.

publications.name: Improved k-NN Regression Model Using Random Forests for Air Pollution Prediction
publications.summary: Developed a model based on KNN algorithm to improve the prediction accuracy of air pollutant concentration.Optimized the weighting function and neighbour selection methods for better results.RMSE in predicting pollutant concentration was decreased by 16‑29% for different gases as compared to existing benchmark.

publications.name: The single Depot multiple Set Orienteering Problem
publications.publisher: Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems
publications.summary: Formalized a problem which is a variant of the orienteering problem.Created efficient constraints to solve the optimization problem using Mixed Integer Linear Programming.Proposed improved subtour elimination constraints having linear number of equations.

publications.name: What changed in the cyber‑security after COVID‑19?
publications.summary: Topic modelling was implemented using Latent Dirichlet Allocation for performing the trend analysis.Coherence measure is used to find the trend in research areas in the Pre‑Covid and ongoing period.The analysis conducted will help researchers see how COVID‑19 impacted various research domains in cyber‑security.

Containerized a simple namenode‑datanode architecture for Hadoop jobs.
Created a simple REST service to invoke Hadoop or Spark jobs based on user query.
Implemented a positivity feature to order files based on presence of keywords.

projects.name: Compiler for custom programming language
highlights: Built lexer based on a definite finite automaton to tokenize input program.
